trans-unit.source: Key operations
trans-unit.target: Key operations

trans-unit.source: Key operations (Azure Search Management REST API)
trans-unit.target: Key operations (Azure Search Management REST API)

trans-unit.source: Authentication to an Azure Search service requires two pieces of information: a search service URL and an api-key.
trans-unit.target: Authentication to an Azure Search service requires two pieces of information: a search service URL and an api-key.

trans-unit.source: The api-keys are generated when the service is created, and can be regenerated on demand after the service is provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The api-keys are generated when the service is created, and can be regenerated on demand after the service is provisioned.

trans-unit.source: There are two types of api-key.
trans-unit.target: There are two types of api-key.

trans-unit.source: Type
trans-unit.target: Type

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Maximum per service
trans-unit.target: Maximum per service

trans-unit.source: Admin
trans-unit.target: Admin

trans-unit.source: Grants access to all operations
trans-unit.target: Grants access to all operations

trans-unit.source: Query
trans-unit.target: Query

trans-unit.source: Authenticates query requests only
trans-unit.target: Authenticates query requests only

trans-unit.source: The ability to programmatically manage the admin and query keys of your Azure Search service gives you the means for building custom tools, rolling over keys periodically as a routine security best practice, rolling over keys when an employee leaves the company, or generating and acquiring keys during service provisioning when a scripted or programmatic approach is used to deploy the solution.
trans-unit.target: The ability to programmatically manage the admin and query keys of your Azure Search service gives you the means for building custom tools, rolling over keys periodically as a routine security best practice, rolling over keys when an employee leaves the company, or generating and acquiring keys during service provisioning when a scripted or programmatic approach is used to deploy the solution.

trans-unit.source: Query keys can be acquired, created, and deleted.
trans-unit.target: Query keys can be acquired, created, and deleted.

trans-unit.source: Admin key operations are restricted to acquiring and regenerating existing key values.
trans-unit.target: Admin key operations are restricted to acquiring and regenerating existing key values.

trans-unit.source: Deleting an admin key could lock you out of the service permanently, so that the operation is not available.
trans-unit.target: Deleting an admin key could lock you out of the service permanently, so that the operation is not available.

trans-unit.source: Keys are strings composed of a random combination of numbers and upper-case letters.
trans-unit.target: Keys are strings composed of a random combination of numbers and upper-case letters.

trans-unit.source: An api-key can only be used with the service for which it was created and could change on a regular basis (if you adopt a key rollover strategy as a security best practice).
trans-unit.target: An api-key can only be used with the service for which it was created and could change on a regular basis (if you adopt a key rollover strategy as a security best practice).

trans-unit.source: Be sure to treat api-keys, especially the admin keys, as sensitive data.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to treat api-keys, especially the admin keys, as sensitive data.

trans-unit.source: Anyone who acquires your admin key has the ability to delete or read data from your indexes.
trans-unit.target: Anyone who acquires your admin key has the ability to delete or read data from your indexes.

trans-unit.target: Operations on keys
